solution_line_template: The total monthly bill for 30 Mbps is ${current_monthly_bill} x {multiplier_30mbps}= $<<{current_monthly_bill}*{multiplier_30mbps}={monthly_bill_30mbps}>>{monthly_bill_30mbps}.
She will have to pay ${monthly_bill_30mbps} x {months_per_year} = $<<{monthly_bill_30mbps}*{months_per_year}={annual_bill_30mbps}>>{annual_bill_30mbps} every year for 30mbps.
The total monthly bill for 20 Mbps is ${current_monthly_bill} + ${additional_cost_20mbps}= $<<{current_monthly_bill}+{additional_cost_20mbps}={monthly_bill_20mbps}>>{monthly_bill_20mbps}.
So, she will have to pay ${monthly_bill_20mbps} x {months_per_year} = $<<{monthly_bill_20mbps}*{months_per_year}={annual_bill_20mbps}>>{annual_bill_20mbps} for 20 Mbps per year.

Therefore the amount she will save per year if she chooses the 20mbps is ${annual_bill_30mbps} - ${annual_bill_20mbps} = $<<{annual_bill_30mbps}-{annual_bill_20mbps}={annual_savings}>>{annual_savings}
